framework_metadata.name: KS2 English Grammar, Punctuation and Spelling Test Framework 2016
framework_metadata.subject: English

test_papers.name: Paper 2: Spelling
test_papers.description: spelling (20 words presented within contextualised sentences, administered aurally)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Nouns (word class)
content_domain_codes.description: Nouns (word class)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Verbs (word class)
content_domain_codes.description: Verbs (word class)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Adjectives (word class)
content_domain_codes.description: Adjectives (word class)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Conjunctions – expressing time, place and cause using conjunctions (e.g. when, b
content_domain_codes.description: Conjunctions – expressing time, place and cause using conjunctions (e.g. when, before, after, while, so, because)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Pronouns – appropriate choice of pronoun or noun within and across sentences to
content_domain_codes.description: Pronouns – appropriate choice of pronoun or noun within and across sentences to aid cohesion and avoid repetition

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Possessive pronouns
content_domain_codes.description: Possessive pronouns

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Relative pronouns
content_domain_codes.description: Relative pronouns

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Adverbs – the use of –ly in Standard English to turn adjectives into adverbs; ex
content_domain_codes.description: Adverbs – the use of –ly in Standard English to turn adjectives into adverbs; expressing time, place and cause using adverbs; indicating degrees of possibility

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Adverbials – expressing time, place and cause using adverbials
content_domain_codes.description: Adverbials – expressing time, place and cause using adverbials

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Prepositions – expressing time, place and cause using prepositions (e.g. before,
content_domain_codes.description: Prepositions – expressing time, place and cause using prepositions (e.g. before, after, during, in, because of)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Determiners – use of the forms a or an according to whether the next word begins
content_domain_codes.description: Determiners – use of the forms a or an according to whether the next word begins with a consonant or a vowel

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Subject and object
content_domain_codes.description: Subject and object

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Statements – how the grammatical patterns in a sentence indicate its function as
content_domain_codes.description: Statements – how the grammatical patterns in a sentence indicate its function as a statement

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Questions – how the grammatical patterns in a sentence indicate its function as
content_domain_codes.description: Questions – how the grammatical patterns in a sentence indicate its function as a question, e.g. the use of question tags

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Commands – how the grammatical patterns in a sentence indicate its function as a
content_domain_codes.description: Commands – how the grammatical patterns in a sentence indicate its function as a command

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Exclamations starting with what or how (e.g. What a good friend you are!)
content_domain_codes.description: Exclamations starting with what or how (e.g. What a good friend you are!)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Sentences and clauses – the boundary between independent (main) clauses
content_domain_codes.description: Sentences and clauses – the boundary between independent (main) clauses

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Relative clauses beginning with who, which, where, when, whose, that, or an omit
content_domain_codes.description: Relative clauses beginning with who, which, where, when, whose, that, or an omitted relative pronoun

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Noun phrases – expanded noun phrases for description and specification; noun phr
content_domain_codes.description: Noun phrases – expanded noun phrases for description and specification; noun phrases expanded by modifying adjectives, nouns and preposition phrases

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Co-ordinating conjunctions – co-ordination using or, and and but
content_domain_codes.description: Co-ordinating conjunctions – co-ordination using or, and and but

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Subordinating conjunctions and subordinate clauses – subordination using when, i
content_domain_codes.description: Subordinating conjunctions and subordinate clauses – subordination using when, if, that and because; extending range of sentences with conjunctions including when, if, because, although

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Simple past tense and simple present tense
content_domain_codes.description: Simple past tense and simple present tense

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Verbs in the perfect form – use of the present perfect form of verbs to mark rel
content_domain_codes.description: Verbs in the perfect form – use of the present perfect form of verbs to mark relationships of time and cause

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Modal verbs – indicating degrees of possibility using modal verbs
content_domain_codes.description: Modal verbs – indicating degrees of possibility using modal verbs

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Present and past progressives – use of the progressive form of verbs in the pres
content_domain_codes.description: Present and past progressives – use of the progressive form of verbs in the present and past tense to mark actions in progress

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Tense consistency – correct choice and consistent use of present and past tense
content_domain_codes.description: Tense consistency – correct choice and consistent use of present and past tense throughout writing

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Subjunctive verb forms – recognising subjunctive forms
content_domain_codes.description: Subjunctive verb forms – recognising subjunctive forms

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Passive and active – use of the passive to affect the presentation of informatio
content_domain_codes.description: Passive and active – use of the passive to affect the presentation of information in a sentence

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Capital letters for names of people, places, days of the week, and the personal
content_domain_codes.description: Capital letters for names of people, places, days of the week, and the personal pronoun I; capital letters to demarcate sentences

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Full stops to demarcate sentences
content_domain_codes.description: Full stops to demarcate sentences

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Question marks to demarcate sentences
content_domain_codes.description: Question marks to demarcate sentences

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Exclamation marks to demarcate sentences
content_domain_codes.description: Exclamation marks to demarcate sentences

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Commas to separate items in a list
content_domain_codes.description: Commas to separate items in a list

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Commas to clarify meaning or avoid ambiguity
content_domain_codes.description: Commas to clarify meaning or avoid ambiguity

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Commas after fronted adverbials
content_domain_codes.description: Commas after fronted adverbials

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Inverted commas and other punctuation to indicate direct speech (e.g. a comma af
content_domain_codes.description: Inverted commas and other punctuation to indicate direct speech (e.g. a comma after the reporting clause; end punctuation within inverted commas)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Apostrophes to mark singular possession; apostrophes to mark plural possession;
content_domain_codes.description: Apostrophes to mark singular possession; apostrophes to mark plural possession; apostrophes to mark contracted forms

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Punctuation for parenthesis – brackets, dashes or commas to indicate parenthesis
content_domain_codes.description: Punctuation for parenthesis – brackets, dashes or commas to indicate parenthesis

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Colons – colon to mark the boundary between independent clauses; colon to introd
content_domain_codes.description: Colons – colon to mark the boundary between independent clauses; colon to introduce lists

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Semi-colons – semi-colon to mark the boundary between independent clauses; semi-
content_domain_codes.description: Semi-colons – semi-colon to mark the boundary between independent clauses; semi-colons within lists

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Single dashes – dash to mark the boundary between independent clauses
content_domain_codes.description: Single dashes – dash to mark the boundary between independent clauses

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Hyphens – how hyphens can be used to avoid ambiguity
content_domain_codes.description: Hyphens – how hyphens can be used to avoid ambiguity

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Bullet points to list information
content_domain_codes.description: Bullet points to list information

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Synonyms and antonyms – how words are related by meaning as synonyms and antonym
content_domain_codes.description: Synonyms and antonyms – how words are related by meaning as synonyms and antonyms

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Prefixes – un– changes meaning of verbs/adjectives; formation of nouns using pre
content_domain_codes.description: Prefixes – un– changes meaning of verbs/adjectives; formation of nouns using prefixes (super–, anti–, auto–); verb prefixes (dis–, de–, mis–, over– and re–)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Suffixes – –ment, –ness, –ful, –less and –ly; formation of nouns using –ness, –e
content_domain_codes.description: Suffixes – –ment, –ness, –ful, –less and –ly; formation of nouns using –ness, –er; formation of adjectives using –ful, –less; converting nouns/adjectives into verbs using –ate, –ise, –ify; singular/plural suffixes

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Word families based on common words, showing how words are related in form and m
content_domain_codes.description: Word families based on common words, showing how words are related in form and meaning

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Standard English – standard verb forms (I did / I done, We were / was); pronouns
content_domain_codes.description: Standard English – standard verb forms (I did / I done, We were / was); pronouns (them / those, that / what); adverbs (run quickly / quick)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Formal and informal vocabulary – the difference between informal speech and form
content_domain_codes.description: Formal and informal vocabulary – the difference between informal speech and formal writing (e.g. ask for / request)

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: Formal and informal structures – the difference between structures typical of in
content_domain_codes.description: Formal and informal structures – the difference between structures typical of informal speech and formal speech and writing

content_domain_codes.substrand_name: The subjunctive – vocabulary and structures appropriate for formal speech and wr
content_domain_codes.description: The subjunctive – vocabulary and structures appropriate for formal speech and writing, including subjunctive forms

content_domain_codes.description: Common exception words
